It isn't a coincidence. The reason why we see colors is because materials have pigments, which reflect specific wavelengths of light(i.e a blue pigment reflects blue wavelengths, but absorbs all the other wavelengths) Since the laser is blue, that means that objects that are more "blue" will reflect more energy than objects that aren't blue. Of course, white objects reflect all wavelengths of visible light, so that is why the white balloon does not pop.

Now to the reason why the white took longer is not due to scattering, but to diffusion. as Johan said, it does not absorb as much energy, just like shirts in the summer, white shirt lets you keep mostly cool and a black gets hot really quickly in the sun.

Lasers get their baloon popping ability due to the light from the [Stimulated Emission of Radiation(light)] That low wavelength laser diode, probably a 405nm or 445nm has a power of probably 1W(445nm) or 800mW(405nm). Lower wavelengths have a higher energy desnity allowing more of a reaction from the same level of power across different wavelengths(nm) eg. a 1W 670nm(IR) laser will not have nearly as much burning power as a 405nm(Violet).

It actually pops one of the white balloons at 2:54... was there a reason that one popped, and the other one didn't?

@mrrsmurf The white ones don't pop because they are light, but be cause they scatter all wavelengths of light. A red balloon scatters only red, and absorbs the others (and heats up and pops). A blue balloon scatters blue light (like the laser) but not perfectly (the colour must be slightly off) so only absorbs a little.

So I'm assuming that the blue balloons didn't pop as fast because they were scattering the light similar to the color of them. What it theoretically you had a balloon that was the exact color of the laser, it would be scattering all the light, so would it not pop like the white ones?

@Xxnightwolf66xX  The heating that popped the balloons is related to the power density of the laser. How much power you have per area. 

The laser here will be slightly divergent, so the spot size will increase the further away you go. I'm sure you could see the laser for miles, but at that distance the spot size will be much bigger, so you won't get the same localised heating to pop the balloon.

@MarvinsDadd 
It's a Class IV LASER, which is classified as a fire hazard.  "Super Duper" is the term you should use when describing it.  It's uses 3 diodes that are collimated to create one very very strong beam.  We can't see the beam with our goggles on, we just practiced knowing where the beam was and were EXTREMELY CAREFUL.  This is over 3 Watts of Optical power (not electrical).
